title: Fearless little girl stares down iconic Wall Street Charging Bull in show of defiance for International Women's Day

As women around the world prepare to draw attention to their role in the workplace, a statue of a little girl appeared in front of New York's well-known bronze charging bull. 
The diminutive, school-age child fearlessly stares down the massive beast in a symbolic act of defiance on International Women's Day . 
The statue was placed in front of the famous tourist attraction in Lower Manhattan by a Wall Street firm on Tuesday evening. 
State Street Global Advisors said it was a way of calling attention to the lack of gender diversity on corporate boards and the pay gap of women working in financial services. Read More The fearless little girl stands in front of the Charging Bull statue (Photo: REUTERS) The guerrilla art marks International Women's Day (Photo: REUTERS) 
"A lot of people talk about gender diversity, but we really felt we had to take it to a broader level," said spokeswoman Anne McNally. 
In conjunction with International Women's Day, many women are planning to stay home from work, which has led some schools to cancel classes. 
Organisers asked women who cannot afford to miss a day of work to limit their shopping to female-owned businesses or to wear red. The bull is a famous tourist spot in Lower Manhattan (Photo: REUTERS) The bronze statue of the little girl was placed there by a Wall Street firm (Photo: REUTERS) 
Although women have made some headway against the glass ceiling, State Street said one out of four of the companies that make up the Russell 3000 Index still have no female representation on their boards. 
"Today, we are calling on companies to take concrete steps to increase gender diversity on their boards, and have issued clear guidance to help them begin to take action," State Street Global Advisors CEO Ron O'Hanley said. Read More Arsenal star Danielle Carter admits on International Women's Day she relishes being a role model for next generation People look at a statue of a girl facing the Wall St. Bull (Photo: REUTERS) 
Much the same as the charging bull, the little bronze girl by artist Kristen Visbal was put up in the wee hours of the morning as "guerilla art," McNally said. 
But, unlike the bull, the firm discussed it with the city beforehand so that it could remain at least temporarily. 
"We're actively pursuing that it stays for a month," she said. "If the city decides that it should stay in perpetuity, we're absolutely on board with that." The diminutive little girl states down the huge bull (Photo: REUTERS) The statue is located at the bottom of Broadway (Photo: REUTERS) 
The bull, sculpted by Italian-born artist Arturo Di Modica, was initially taken down after he quietly placed it in front of the New York Stock Exchange in December 1989. 
But it was later given a permanent home, about a five-minute walk away on Broadway, in response to public support. Like us on Facebook
